close_symbols: struct lfs_t (layout of fields used by lfs_init: cfg, block_count, rcache, pcache, lookahead, name_max, file_max, attr_max, inline_max, root, mlist, seed, gdisk, gstate, gdelta, lfs1)

struct lfs_config (all fields referenced by lfs_init: block_count, disk_version, read, prog, erase, sync, read_size, prog_size, cache_size, block_size, block_cycles, compact_thresh, metadata_max, lookahead_size, read_buffer, prog_buffer, lookahead_buffer, name_max, file_max, attr_max, inline_max)
LFS_ASSERT macro (definition/expansion and whether it compiles to executable checks or no-ops)
LFS_ERR_NOMEM (numeric error code used on allocation failure)
LFS_NAME_MAX, LFS_FILE_MAX, LFS_ATTR_MAX (limit constants used to bound name_max/file_max/attr_max)
LFS_DISK_VERSION_MAJOR, LFS_DISK_VERSION_MINOR (constants used in the LFS_MULTIVERSION check)
LFS_MULTIVERSION, LFS_READONLY, LFS_MIGRATE (preprocessor configuration macros that change which statements are compiled/executed)
lfs_size_t (the integer type used for sizes like inline_max/compact_thresh/metadata_max)
lfs_npw2 (implementation and side-effects, used inside an assert expression)
lfs_malloc (semantics: allocation, side-effects, and failure behavior)
lfs_cache_zero (implementation and side-effects; zeroing caches may be observable)
lfs_min (implementation used to compute default inline_max)
lfs_deinit (implementation and side-effects; called on cleanup and may free/reset state)
lfs_free (called by lfs_deinit; needed to understand resource release done by cleanup)
types/layout of rcache/pcache/lookahead structures (at least the buffer field and any bookkeeping the helpers expect)
lfs_gstate_t type (used for zero-initialization of gdisk/gstate/gdelta)
explanation:
For determining whether any statement in lfs_init qualifies as "dead code" (i.e., executed but removable without changing program behaviour), the analyzer must know not only the syntactic operations but the semantics and side-effects of all involved symbols and compile-time configuration that affect control flow. Concretely:

- struct lfs_t and struct lfs_config: lfs_init performs many assignments to fields of these types. To know whether an assignment is necessary (used later by callers or other code) you must know the exact layout and which fields are read elsewhere. The analyzer needs the field names, types and whether writes have observable side-effects.

- LFS_ASSERT: whether assertions generate runtime checks (that can affect behaviour) or are compiled out is critical. If assertions are no-ops in the target build, the contained expressions (including calls like lfs_npw2) may not be executed — changing whether code is dead.

- All numeric constants and types (LFS_ERR_NOMEM, LFS_BLOCK_NULL, LFS_NAME_MAX, LFS_FILE_MAX, LFS_ATTR_MAX, lfs_size_t, disk-version constants): these determine conditional logic and bounds. Removing assignments that merely set values equal to defaults or constants could be dead only if those constants and subsequent uses make the assignments redundant.

- Preprocessor feature flags (LFS_MULTIVERSION, LFS_READONLY, LFS_MIGRATE): these control which checks and assignments are present in the compiled binary. Dead-code analysis must consider the exact build configuration.

- lfs_npw2, lfs_malloc, lfs_cache_zero, lfs_min: these functions are called from lfs_init. You must know whether they have side-effects (e.g., heap/stack/global state, hardware interactions) or always pure computations. For example, lfs_cache_zero zeros memory — removing that call could change behaviour (information leakage, or subsequent reads). lfs_malloc can fail and its allocation affects later behavior; lfs_min affects computed defaults.

- lfs_deinit and lfs_free: the cleanup path calls lfs_deinit which in turn frees resources. To decide if cleanup code (and earlier assignments that lead to cleanup) are needed, the analyzer must know what deinit does. Also, whether setting fields before calling deinit has any observable effect.

- rcache/pcache/lookahead structure layouts and lfs_gstate_t: initialization of these substructures (including the (type){0} zero-inits) may be required for correct subsequent behaviour; whether those initializations are redundant depends on their definitions and how other code reads them.

In short, the listed symbols provide the semantic context (types, constants, called-function side-effects, and compile-time options) required to decide whether each executed operation in lfs_init can be removed without affecting program behaviour, which is the essence of the MISRA dead-code check.
